"**Forgot About Dre** " is a [Grammy Award](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy
Award")-winning single from rapper [Dr. Dre](/wiki/Dr._Dre "Dr. Dre")'s
_[2001](/wiki/2001_\(Dr._Dre_album\) "2001 \(Dr. Dre album\)")_ , featuring
vocals from rapper [Eminem](/wiki/Eminem "Eminem"). The track reached No. 25
on the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"), No.
14 on the U.S. R&B chart, No. 32 on the U.S. Pop chart, and No. 7 on the [UK
Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart"). Released as the
album's second single on January 29, 2000,[1] like "[Still
D.R.E.](/wiki/Still_D.R.E. "Still D.R.E.")", the song addresses Dre's critics
in a defiant manner, as Dre announces his return to the hip-hop scene and
reminds listeners of his significant influence on the genre. "Forgot About
Dre" won [Best Rap Performance by a Duo or
Group](/wiki/Best_Rap_Performance_by_a_Duo_or_Group "Best Rap Performance by a
Duo or Group") at the [2001 Grammy Awards](/wiki/2001_Grammy_Awards "2001
Grammy Awards").[2]

## Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Forgot_About_Dre&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(August 2012)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
The song is considered to be a response to [diss tracks](/wiki/Diss_\(music\)
"Diss \(music\)") made by [Death Row](/wiki/Death_Row_Records "Death Row
Records") artists on _[Suge Knight Represents: Chronic
2000](/wiki/Suge_Knight_Represents:_Chronic_2000 "Suge Knight Represents:
Chronic 2000")_ , a compilation released by [Suge Knight](/wiki/Suge_Knight
"Suge Knight") which takes its title from Dre's 1992 album _[The
Chronic](/wiki/The_Chronic "The Chronic")_. The line "Who you think brought
you the oldies, [Eazy-E](/wiki/Eazy-E "Eazy-E")'s, [Ice Cube](/wiki/Ice_Cube
"Ice Cube")'s, and [D.O.C.](/wiki/The_D.O.C. "The D.O.C.")'s, the [Snoop D.O.
Double G](/wiki/Snoop_Dogg "Snoop Dogg")'s, and [the group that
said](/wiki/N.W.A "N.W.A") ['Motherfuck the police](/wiki/Fuck_tha_Police
"Fuck tha Police")'?" outlines Dre's importance in the rap world, the theme of
the song. Eminem's verse features the bizarre violence and aggression typical
of his "Slim Shady" alter ego.[3]

## Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Forgot_About_Dre&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Music video")]

In the [music video](/wiki/Music_video "Music video"), a few explicit lines in
Eminem's verse are replaced with a skit in which Eminem is answering reporter
Jane Yamamoto's questions about a fire he and Dre had started.[4] It also
features [Hittman](/wiki/Hittman "Hittman"), who was not in the song. This
video won the [MTV Video Music Award for Best Rap
Video](/wiki/MTV_Video_Music_Award_for_Best_Rap_Video "MTV Video Music Award
for Best Rap Video") in 2000.

## Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Forgot_About_Dre&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

Stephen Thomas Erlewine of [AllMusic](/wiki/AllMusic "AllMusic") marked it as
a stand-out track praising Eminem's unpredictability.[5] _[NME](/wiki/NME
"NME")_ described this song: "In case folks been smoking too much heavy
'chronic' lately, West Coast rap founder and scary legend Andre Young, aka Dr
Dre, jogs their memories on 'Forgot About Dre'. "Who you think brought you the
OGs, Eazy Es, Ice Cubes and DOCs, the Snoop- D-O-G-Gs and the group that said
motherfuck the police?" yammers the one-time NWA lynchpin, ex Death Row playa,
inventor of - G-Funk and occasional breaker of rival producers' jaws. Yo,
indeed, big bad Dre's back and, despite a four-year gap since his last
hardcore missive, the Doc's recent collaboration with Eminem on 'The Slim
Shady LP' has kept his legend simmering."[6] Chris Massey of PopMatters
praised: "[...] it’s the frantic rap of Eminem that truly stands out, perhaps
only because he’s the freshest voice on board."[7] Greg Tate of _SPIN_
magazine noted that Dr. Dre uses this song to make sure all recognize his
"majesty" with Eminem standing by him like a cartoon pitbull.[8]
